title: Alliance Films
text:
Alliance Films (formerly Alliance Entertainment, Alliance Communications, Alliance Atlantis Releasing Ltd, Motion Picture Distribution LP and also known as Alliance Vivafilm in Quebec and also known simply as Alliance) was a Canadian motion picture distribution and production company, which had served Canada, the United Kingdom, and Spain.
Because <a href="Entertainment%20One">Entertainment One</a> acquired Alliance Films in early 2013, it was dissolved into that company. It was one of the major motion picture companies to distribute <a href="independent%20film">independent film</a>s outside the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> and other countries.
History.
Prior to the company (1984–1998).
The company was formed in 1984 by Stephen Roth, <a href="Denis%20H%C3%A9roux">Denis Héroux</a>, <a href="John%20Kemeny%20%28film%20producer%29">John Kemeny</a>, <a href="Robert%20Lantos">Robert Lantos</a>, Andras Hamori and Susan Cavan as Alliance Entertainment, from a merger of RSL Entertainment Corporation and International Cinema Corporation, with financing from New Century Entertainment's SLM Productions and gave them a $10 million fund.
In 1986, the company had completed the first six projects in the first twelve months, and the company's fare was to be shown on <a href="Big%20Three%20TV%20Networks">the Big Three networks</a>, namely <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>, <a href="CBS">CBS</a> and <a href="NBC">NBC</a>, as well as cable channel <a href="HBO">HBO</a> and Canadian channel <a href="CTV%20Television%20Network">CTV</a>, as well as a financing agreement with New Century/SLM Productions. One of Alliance's well known TV projects was "<a href="Night%20Heat">Night Heat</a>", and had to develop several television miniseries.
It acquired a Montreal-based Francophone distribution company, Vivafilm, in 1990. In 1998, it merged with Atlantis Communications, forming <a href="Alliance%20Atlantis">Alliance Atlantis Communications</a>.
Later years (2007–2013).
In partnership with <a href="Cineplex%20Entertainment">Cineplex Entertainment</a>, Alliance Films (operating as Motion Picture Distribution LP under <a href="Alliance%20Atlantis">Alliance Atlantis</a>) also operated <a href="Alliance%20Cinemas">Alliance Cinemas</a>, owner of two <a href="Toronto">Toronto</a>-area theatres. During the MPD era, all materials relating to Alliance Atlantis–distributed films contained a disclaimer stating that Alliance Atlantis was "an indirect limited partner of Motion Picture Distribution LP, not a general partner". However, in fact, the company controlled the general partner of the partnership, and hence effectively controlled the distribution unit itself.
Formerly known as Motion Picture Distribution LP, it was rebranded and relaunched in 2007 due to the collapse of its preceding company, <a href="Alliance%20Atlantis">Alliance Atlantis</a>, which was sold off piece by piece to <a href="CanWest%20Global">CanWest Global</a>, <a href="Goldman%20Sachs%23GS%20Capital%20Partners">GS Capital Partners</a>, along with several other smaller companies. <a href="Soci%C3%A9t%C3%A9%20g%C3%A9n%C3%A9rale%20de%20financement">Société générale de financement du Québec</a>, an investment agency of the provincial government, owns 51% of the voting shares of the company and 38.5% of the equity. GS Capital owns the remainder of the company.
Alliance Films was headquartered in <a href="Montreal">Montreal</a>, <a href="Quebec">Quebec</a>, in the <a href="Quartier%20International">Quartier International</a>.
In the mid-2000s, Alliance Films began to produce films in moderation. In addition to producing films as "<a href="The%20Rocket%20%282005%20film%29">The Rocket</a> (Maurice Richard)" with <a href="Cin%C3%A9maginaire">Cinémaginaire</a> (as well as other movies), "<a href="National%20Lampoon%27s%20Senior%20Trip">National Lampoon's Senior Trip</a>" with New Line Cinema and "<a href="Munich%20%282005%20film%29">Munich</a>" with Universal Pictures, DreamWorks SKG and Amblin Entertainment of and before the days of <a href="Alliance%20Atlantis">Alliance Atlantis</a> respectively, they were responsible for co-producing the 2008 teen slasher "<a href="Prom%20Night%20%282008%20film%29">Prom Night</a>" with <a href="Screen%20Gems">Screen Gems</a> and <a href="Original%20Film">Original Film</a>. They also produced and distributed the war drama "<a href="Passchendaele%20%28film%29">Passchendaele</a>", and co-produced the comedy "<a href="Stone%20of%20Destiny%20%28film%29">Stone of Destiny</a>" with Infinity Features Entertainment and <a href="The%20Mob%20Film%20Company">The Mob Film Company</a>. They are also responsible for co-producing the 2011 horror film "<a href="Insidious%20%28film%29">Insidious</a>" with FilmDistrict and "<a href="Wanderlust%20%282011%20film%29">Wanderlust</a>" with Universal Pictures and Apatow Productions.
In 2010, Alliance Films expanded its home video operations with an aggressive push into the TV-on-DVD market. It began releasing various television series on DVD, the majority are Canadian productions or Canadian co-productions. To date they have released over 20 series and continue to release more.
On June 24, 2011, Alliance Films bought <a href="Maple%20Pictures">Maple Pictures</a> from <a href="Lionsgate">Lionsgate</a> for a total of $38.5 million before Alliance was folded into Entertainment One in early 2013.
Since early 2010, Alliance Films has been partnering with Jason Blum and his BlumHouse Productions to produce low budget horror films. This began with "<a href="Insidious%20%28film%29">Insidious</a>" which was released in 2011. The next to be released was "<a href="Sinister%20%28film%29">Sinister</a>" in 2012 and "<a href="Dark%20Skies%20%282013%20film%29">Dark Skies</a>" in 2013. Since the 2013 acquisition and absorption, it is unclear if eOne will be a partner on subsequent BlumHouse films and their sequels.
On January 3, 2012, it was announced that Goldman Sachs Group is looking to sell its majority stake in Alliance Films.
Acquisition by eOne.
On May 28, 2012, <a href="Entertainment%20One">Entertainment One</a> confirmed their bid to purchase Alliance Films from Goldman Sachs Group, similar to the purchase of <a href="Maple%20Pictures">Maple Pictures</a> a year prior. The acquisition was completed on January 9, 2013; upon the closure of the deal, Victor Loewy stepped down as CEO of the company. eOne also announced that it would phase out the Alliance brand entirely, in favour of solely operating under the eOne banner.
